subject: RE: [junit] How would you test a code which is used in Multi-threaded context
msgSnippet: Sal, In testGetAndPutWithThread() It doesn t look like you re starting your thread.  Also, I don t see any asserts in testGetAndPutWithThread(). What exactly
messageBody:
Sal,

In testGetAndPutWithThread() It doesn't look like you're starting your
thread. Also, I don't see any asserts in testGetAndPutWithThread().
What exactly is failing is this test?

Kris


>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: shailesh401 [mailto:skadam@...]
> Sent: Monday, October 06, 2003 8:33 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>
> Guys,
> Testing the following code in 1 thread is easy, but
> in multiple thread is confusing...
>
> 1st test passes, 2nd one fail.
>
> Any suggestions or help.
>
> Thanks
> Sal
>
>
> -------------- SynchronizedQueue.java ----------------
>
> import java.util.Vector;
>
> public class SynchronizedQueue {
> private Vector elements = new Vector(10,10);
>
> public synchronized Object get() {
> while (elements.isEmpty()) {
> try {
> wait();
> } catch (InterruptedException e) {
> }
> }
> notifyAll();
> Object anElement = elements.remove(0);
> return anElement;
> }
>
> public synchronized void put(Object anElement) {
> elements.add(anElement);
> notifyAll();
> }
> }
>
> ------------------ SynchronizedQueueTest ----------------------------
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
>
> import java.util.Vector;
>
> public class SynchronizedQueueTest extends TestCase {
>
> public void testGetAndPutWithoutThreads() throws Exception {
> final SynchronizedQueue synchronizedQueue = new
> SynchronizedQueue();
> synchronizedQueue.put("111");
> synchronizedQueue.put("222");
> synchronizedQueue.put("333");
> assertEquals("111", synchronizedQueue.get());
> assertEquals("222", synchronizedQueue.get());
> assertNotSame("444", synchronizedQueue.get());
> }
>
> public void testGetAndPutWithThread() throws Exception {
> Vector elements = new Vector();
> SynchronizedQueue synchronizedQueue = new SynchronizedQueue();
> new Thread() {
> public void run() {
> elements.add(synchronizedQueue.get());
> elements.add(synchronizedQueue.get());
> }
> };
> synchronizedQueue.put("FirstElement");
> synchronizedQueue.put("SecondElement");
> elements.add(synchronizedQueue.get());
> synchronizedQueue.put("ThirdElement");
> elements.toString();
> }
> }
>
>
>
>
